item.title: Shrimp Quesadillas
item.description:
My apologies for posting another shrimp recipe so soon, but it is just such a great summer option! It is an easily-attainable, pretty affordable seafood option. It is nice to switch up classics with new flavors. That is just what I did here. Most people think of chicken, beef, or pork in their quesadillas, but swapping out meat for seafood is a great alternative. The shrimp is bold and spicy, the corn is sweet and fresh, and the scallions and beans are great additions. When pressed together with gooey cheddar cheese, each bite is bursting with great flavors! These are fun to serve cut up as an appetizer with a side of sour cream and tomatoes. You can also have them as a main meal with a vegetable or rice side, which is what we did. This is a great summer meal!

Quesadillas

  • 1/2 lb peeled and deveined shrimp
  • flour tortillas - 2 per quesadilla (this made 5)
  • chipotle in adobo, just the sauce
  • 1 corn cob - kernels removed
  • ½ can black beans
  • 1 scallion - sliced thin
  • cheddar cheese - grated

Toppings

  • Pico : diced tomato, diced red onion, diced jalapeno, cilantro
  • sour cream

I started this off by marinating my shrimp for about half an hour while I was preparing other things. I dried off my shrimp, added salt and pepper, and brushed them with chipotle sauce. I elf the actual peppers in the can and just used the sauce. That gives plenty of spice! They do not need long to marinate.

To make the filling for the quesadillas, start by cooking the shrimp. I made them on my indoor grill. You can grill them or pan fry them, whatever is easiest. If they are small like mine were, they only need a few minutes in each side. Once cooked, add them to a medium sized bowl. To that bowl, add you cooked corn kernels, black beans and scallions. This will be you filling.

If you have a panini or sandwich press, you can use this to press the quesadillas. If not, you can press them in a pan with a heavy pan on top. Add a tortilla to the bottom, add the filling leaving a small border around the edges and pile the cheese on top. Place another tortilla on top then close the lid and let it cook until the cheese is melted. Flip the tortilla carefully and let the other side cook until finished! You can serve these in a whole circle with a big dollop of sour cream and pico or you can cut them into wedges and top each wedge with the goodies. Delicious any which way you slice it!

item.title: Poppin' Cherry Chicken
item.description:
Here we have a perfect summer meal. Summertime is the best time for tomatoes to shine. This recipe is my spin on the classic chicken parm. The chicken is crispy and flavorful. The spinach is healthy and garlicky. The tomatoes are sweet and burst with flavor in your mouth. The cheese on top is ooey and gooey and ties everything together.

We had this for Sunday dinner for my brother and his girlfriend. It was pretty fun to have extra hands in the kitchen to help with the prep. So bring your family, friends, and kids into the kitchen and make this before summer is over!

  • 1 cup flour
  • 3 eggs
  • 2 cups bread crumbs ( I used seasoned)
  • *6 thin sliced chicken breasts
  • 1 pint cherry tomatoes
  • 8 oz fresh mozzarella
  • 1 bag spinach
  • 2 cloves of garlic - minced

*the chicken must be sliced thin - if you buy the large chicken breasts, cut them in half lengthwise

For this meal, I find it best to prep all of the parts and then assemble the chicken and bake.

For the chicken breading :
Begin by setting up your breading station. Add the flour, eggs, and breadcrumbs each into a separate container. Pat your chicken dry and add salt and pepper. Next, dip the chicken in flour, then into the egg, and finally into the breadcrumbs. Set on a late until you are ready to pan-fry. Once you are ready to cook, shallow fry each piece in enough olive oil to coat the pan. Since they are thin, they will cook quickly - 3-4 minutes per side. Once cooked, add to a paper towel to drain.

Cherry Tomatoes :
Add oil, salt, and pepper to tomatoes and roast on 350 degrees for 20 minutes. You want the tomatoes to be at the point where they just burst (see below).

Spinach :
Saute in olive oil to wilt the spinach down. After about 5-7 minutes when it is cooked, add a pinch of salt and pepper and the minced garlic.

For the Dish :
Take a piece of chicken and add the spinach on top. Next, add the cherry tomatoes and mozzarella cheese. Since everything is already cooked at this point, we just want to melt the cheese. Put your oven on the broil setting and broil the chicken on the top rack for 2-3 minutes until cheese is melted and bubbly.

I served this alongside a simple pasta with the rest of the roasted tomatoes from the prep, roasted garlic, and parmesan cheese.

item.title: Summer Corn Salad
item.description:
This type of salad seems to be a staple in my family for most summer BBQ’s. Since summer corn has such a small window, we make the most of it as long as we can. When we enjoy corn on the cob, we usually leave the husk on the corn and grill it just like that. For this, I thought I would switch it up and boil the corn then use my indoor grill since the weather was bad. This makes it an easy option if you are already in the kitchen cooking. However, if you are already grilling, throw those babies on the grill and you’ll have the same outcome. The salad is light and refreshing for the summer weather and pairs nicely with most meat and seafood dishes.

  • 1 pint cherry tomatoes
  • 6 ears corn
  • 8 oz small mozzarella balls
  • 2 scallions- sliced thin
  • 1-2 tbsp honey
  • juice of 3-4 limes ~ 1/3 cup

Begin by slicing the mozzarella balls in half. If the cherry tomatoes are large, you can slice these in half too. Slice the scallions and set all of these in a large bowl. For the corn, you can grill it or boil it. I did both! A boil to cook it and a quick flip on the grill for color and some char.

I have a great trick for you to get the kernels off that cobb in the easiest and cleanest way possible. See my picture below : place a small bowl upside down in a large bowl, then place the corn cobb on the base of the small bowl and stead it. Using a sharp knife, shave the kernels off from top to bottom, so that they fall nicely in the bowl. So easy!

To make the dressing, it is based on your preference. It is just lime juice with honey, and salt and pepper. You can add more honey for sweetness or more lime for more tartness. Also, if you are making this ahead, you may want to make extra dressing since it will soak into the veggies. This is such a delicious, colorful side dish for any barbeque, picnic, or dinner this summer!

item.title: Blueberry Cheesecake Bars
item.description:
This weekend we celebrated my Dad’s birthday. His one request was that we have a BBQ at his house and everyone makes something. My brother had a menu in mind, so we all split up the dishes evenly. My dad made the steak and lobster, my mom made the chimichurri sauce and sides, my brother made a summer grilled corn salad, Nate made fresh baked bread and trout dip, and I made an appetizer and this dessert! It was so much fun to have this delicious meal come together with everyones help. Everyone had one thing in mind: what does Dad like? That is exactly what inspired this dessert. I wanted to create something summery that my dad would love. Mission accomplished! Blueberry and lemon is a classic flavor combo that we all love. These bars were easy to make and were a great summer treat. They taste even better the next day.

Graham CrackerCrust

  • 1 cup graham crackers - crushed
  • ½ stick butter - melted
  • ½ tsp cinnamon

Cream Cheese Layer

  • 2 8oz packages of cream cheese - softened
  • 2 eggs
  • ½ cup sugar
  • 1 tsp vanilla

Blueberry Pie Layer

  • 1 pint fresh blueberries
  • the zest of 1 lemon
  • 2 tsp cornstarch
  • 2 tbsp sugar

Set oven to 325.

To make the crust : either use a food processor to grind the graham crackers or you can place in a large bag and crush them. Melt the butter and mix the 2 together. Press the mixture into an 8 x 8 square baking dish. I usually spray my dish with PAM non-stick cooking spray to be safe.

For the cream cheese layer : using a food processor or hand mixer, blend the ingredients together. Once blended until smooth, spread evenly on top of graham cracker crust. Place in the oven on 325 degrees for about 30 minutes, until cooked through.

While the bars are baking, make the blueberry filling. In a small saucepan, put blueberries, sugar, and lemon zest in. Heat for about 5 minutes until simmering. Then, add cornstarch and let the mixture simmer for about 5 more minutes until it starts to thicken.

Once the pan comes out of the oven, let it cool slightly. Pour blueberry filling on top to cover the cream cheese layer. At this point, it is best to put in the fridge to chill. Once chilled, you can add more lemon zest on top. Cut the bars into squares and enjoy! We found that they were actually better the second day because everything had a chance to firm up. A great make-ahead summer dish!

item.title: Shrimp Tacos with Mango Salsa
item.description:
It is Taco Tuesday at the Bowser’s and shrimp is on the menu tonight! We love tacos in all shapes, flavors, and forms and have eaten our fair share. I like to switch it up, and use seafood and shrimp in tacos, instead of always pork or beef. The shrimp come out a little spicy and very flavorful, with an added zing from some lime zest. The mango salsa is sweet and also a little spicy from the jalapeno. I like to buy the mangoes when they are on sale and leave them on my counter for a few days to ripen. Then I get to decide what to make with them! The best is just to eat them super ripe and juicy. I like the added crunch of the slaw and the creamy consistency is a nice balance to the taco. Make these for your next taco night!

Shrimp

  • 1 lb peeled and deveined shrimp
  • 1 tsp cumin
  • ½ tsp chili powder
  • ½ tsp garlic powder
  • ½ tsp paprika
  • lime zest from 1 lime
  • ¼ tsp salt
  • corn or flour tortillas

Salsa

  • 1 mango - diced
  • 1 jalapeno - diced fine
  • ¼ red onion - diced fine
  • 1 tbsp cilantro
  • ¼ red pepper - chopped
  • the juice of 1 lime

Slaw

  • ¼ head cabbage - shredded
  • 2 tbsp mayo
  • the juice of 1 lime
  • handful chopped cilantro

For the salsa: Mix ingredients and let the flavors mingle. Set aside.

For the Slaw: Mix the ingredients and let the flavors mingle. Set aside.

For the shrimp : Make sure shrimp are peeled and deveined. Lets be honest, I love it when they are available that way in the store, and even more when they are on sale, but that is not the norm. Set aside some time to prep the shrimp. Make sure shrimp are rinsed, drained, and pat them dry. Add the remaining ingredients from the list (cumin-salt) to the shrimp. At this point, you can let these marinate for a bit, or you can get ready to cook them up. They do not need long to marinate.

You have some options. You can pan fry the shrimp in 1-2 tsp of olive oil, which is what I did. You can also throw the shrimp on skewers and grill them, if the weather permits. I would prefer to grill the shrimp to get a nice char, but it has been raining all day. They are delicious either way!

To serve, add a few shrimp to each tortilla and top with slaw and salsa. Dig in!

item.title: Flounder Puttanesca
item.description:
Flounder! I must say, this is a new fish for me. It all started 2 weeks ago when my family and I went on a birthday dinner for my mom and I. Our birthdays are a month apart, so we settled on a date in the middle. We chose an Italian restaurant and the first special of the night was Flounder Puttanesca. I thought to myself - “I will definitely not be having that, I am not even sure if I like flounder”. My brother decided to order that special and after tasting all of the meals, we unanimously voted his meal as the best meal of the night! There you have it, try new things and they may become new favorites.

Puttanesca sauce is not even something I have often, but it really is simple and delicious. It has a nice salty, briny flavor. I was able to recreate this dish pretty easily and I wanted to share it because it is easy enough for a weeknight meal, but also special enough for a dinner party.

There is one ingredient I would like to address - the anchovies. I think some people may be opposed to trying this in the recipe, but I want to assure you that it will not give the sauce a “fishy” taste. What it will do, is give the sauce an added saltiness and really compliment the flounder. The anchovies basically melt into the sauce and there are not large pieces or bites. You will basically not even know they are in there. I would advise you to try them!

  • 4 flounder fillets, or approximately 1 pound
  • ⅓ cup flour, for dusting
  • canola oil for frying
  • 1 large can whole peeled tomatoes (28 oz)
  • 3 tbsp olive oil
  • ½ cup pitted kalamata olives
  • anchovies packed in oil - 4-5 small fillets
  • 3 oz capers, ~ 3 tbsp
  • 6 garlic cloves, grated or minced fine
  • 1 tsp red pepper flakes (optional)
  • 1 lb pasta - your choice, we used angel hair

Remove flounder and dry the fillets. Add salt and pepper to both sides and then dip each fillet into the flour. You want a light dusting on the fish. Add canola oil to a heavy bottomed pan about an inch up the side. You want to do a shallow fry and not submerge the whole fish in oil. My fillets were pretty thin, so they only needed 3 minutes per side. When you remove them from the oil, put them on a paper-towel lined plate to soak any excess oil.

Add olive oil to a skillet over medium low heat. Add in the sardine fillets and let them cook in the oil. Using a wooden spoon, break them apart. They will melt into the oil and sauce and you will not have chunks in there after a few minutes. Add in the garlic and let everything cook for a minute. Add in capers and cook for another minute. Next, use your hands to crush the whole tomatoes as you add them into the pan. This way, you will have smaller, bite-sized chunks of tomatoes in the sauce. Let the sauce come to a simmer to incorporate all the flavors. After a few minutes, add in the red pepper flakes (if using) and the calamata olives. The sauce doesn’t need to cook much after this, but I would simmer it for a few minutes.

At this point, you can add the pasta into the sauce to mingle. Or, if you prefer, you can serve the pasta topped with sauce, then the fish on top of that and more sauce to finish. I added the pasta into the sauce then served it with a piece of fish on top and more sauce over the whole dish. It was really delicious, fresh, salty, and wonderful!

Manjia!

item.title: Spinach Poppy Salad
item.description:
I want to start by saying that I am sorry for posting another salad recipe this soon, but I absolutely have to share this one! Plus, it’s spring-time and I think we all can use a little more salad in our lives. This dressing is a real winner. It is sweet, savory, and salty, with a nice bite from the onion. The ingredients go nicely together and really compliment and balance each other. This salad makes a great lunch or side for dinner. I think it would also be lovely at a BBQ as a light and fresh option.

As always, of course you can tweak the salad ingredients to use what you have and what you like. That is what I always do, and that is what inspired this salad! Hope you enjoy.

Salad

  • spinach leaves
  • 1 cup cooked whole wheat pasta (optional - I used leftovers)
  • sliced strawberries
  • ½ cup of crumbled feta - to taste
  • handful roasted sunflower seeds

Poppy Seed Dressing

  • ⅓ cup white vinegar
  • ½ cup olive oil
  • 2 tbsp white sugar
  • 2 tbsp grated white onion
  • 1 tsp poppy seeds
  • 1 heaping tbsp dijon mustard

Begin by making the dressing. Add the sugar to the vinegar and whisk until sugar is dissolved, about 2 minutes. Next, add grated onion - I use a regular box grater on the large holes to do this. This will give you the onion flavor without the sharp bite. Add the dijon mustard and then the olive oil and whisk until emulsified. Add the poppy seeds at the end.

Add the spinach and pasta to a large bowl and continue to add each layer on top. Mix with dressing and serve with extra sunflower seeds on top for a little added crunch!
item.dc:creator: Kristina Bowser

item.title: Farro with Mushrooms
item.description:
This is a great little side dish! Let me start by telling you about farro. It is one of my new favorite grains! The thing that I love about it is its texture and its chewiness. In my opinion, it is more interesting than quinoa and couscous. Don’t get me wrong - I love those as well, but quinoa is lacking texture and couscous can just be boring sometimes. That is where farro comes in - to spice things up!

The definition of farro, straight from the wikipedia article is : “a food composed of the grains of certain wheat species. The exact definition is debated.” So you’ll just have to trust me and try it yourself! I find it in my local supermarket with the rice and the grains, but you can sometimes find it in the bulk bins of certain health food stores.

I have been experimenting with it lately, and it can really stand up to most “dressings” and ingredients. Here, I tried to make it a savory side to go with the salmon and asparagus we were having for dinner. The garlic butter is fantastic and really soaks into the farro. Who doesn’t love garlic butter slathered on anything and everything?

Next, I want to take some time to talk about the mushrooms. Mushrooms can be a finicky ingredient if not prepared properly. After some testing around, I think I have found a delicious way to bring out their flavor. Just want to give a shout-out to my friend Kelly for helping me perfect this technique. More on that below…

  • 2 cups farro
  • 4 cups low sodium chicken stock
  • 2 cups water
  • 1 package mushrooms - any kind you like
  • ½ stick of butter
  • 4 cloves of garlic
  • ⅓ cup cooking sherry - available in the supermarket

Begin by bringing the chicken stock and water to boil in a medium sauce pan. I like to always use low sodium chicken stock so I can control the amount of salt in the recipe. Once boiling, add in farro and some salt. You can adjust this later if you didn't add enough. One thing about farro, is that all the liquid does not have to evaporate like it does for rice. Most of the time, you have to drain the farro at the end of cooking it. After you add the farro in, reduce the heat to a simmer and put a lid on it. It will need to cook about 30 minutes until tender but still chewy.

While the farro is cooking , slice your mushrooms if they are not already sliced and heat a saute pan on medium high heat. Put the mushrooms in the pan DRY. No oil, no salt, nothing to begin with. Mushrooms have liquid in them, and when you salt them early, they get watery. Give the mushrooms a few minutes to soften, then they will release liquid for a few minutes and dry up and begin to stick to the pan. At this point, after about 10 minutes, add in the sherry and let the mushrooms cook until they are dry again. Add in salt and a good dose of fresh cracked black pepper. Set aside until farro is done.

In a small saucepan, heat the butter and grate in your garlic using a microplane. You could also just mince finely. Let them melt together.

Drain your farro, place it in a bowl, and then pour the hot garlic butter over top. Smells so good! Top the bowl with the sauted mushrooms and dig in!

item.title: Mango Slaw
item.description:
This is the slaw I served alongside the double bean burgers I posted earlier this week. It is so perfect for the grilling season and will be a great accompaniment to your BBQ’s. It comes together in no-time and all the ingredients are fresh. I have a feeling this will be on a regular rotation through the spring and summer cook-out season. It is crunchy, tangy, and sweet from the mango. What more could you ask for?

  • 1/4 cup greek yogurt
  • ¼ cup mayo
  • lime juice - 1/2 a lime
  • 1 tsp dijon
  • 1 tsp sugar
  • * ½ tsp celery seeds
  • ½ small green cabbage - shredded
  • ½ small red cabbage - shredded
  • 1 ripe mango - peeled and sliced thin
  • ½ red pepper - sliced thin

*I used ½ tsp of celery salt, so I omitted any extra salt. If you use plain celery seed, you may still need to add a pinch of salt.

First, make the dressing. Combine all the ingredients, mix, and taste for seasoning.

Chop and slice all your veggies and mango. Add in dressing and put it in the fridge so the flavors can meld. I did not use all the dressing. I would start with half, and then adjust from there. Sometimes, after it sits a while, it soaks up dressing and you need to add more later, so save some.

This is really a perfect side dish for any BBQ, burgers, grilled chicken, seafood, and everything! The best part is, it gets better the longer it sits, so it is a perfect make-ahead dish.

You’ll want to save this recipe for your upcoming summer BBQ’s!
item.dc:creator: Kristina Bowser

item.title: Double Bean Burgers
item.description:
My husband and I can both agree - my black bean burger game has come a LONG way! I have been “attempting” to make non-mushy black bean burgers for years now, and I am happy to say that I have finally mastered it! I’m sure many of you have tried to make some form of bean burgers and they have not been the consistency you were hoping for. I have tried pan frying, baking, and even grilling. I would not try grilling, trust me. However, I have had great success in the combination of freezing the burgers, baking the burgers on high heat, then broiling them, which gives you a “burger-like” consistency and can stand up on a bun.

These are so great because they are an awesome meat free option, very filling, and you can play around with the ingredients and toppings to make what you like. I used a mixture of black beans and cannellini beans because I think the cannellini beans are so smooth and creamy that they balance out the black beans. You can add more or less spice with the jalapenos and chili powder. The toppings I used really compliment the black bean burger nicely, but the sky's the limit!

The chipotle mayo is so smoky and a bit spicy, the avocado is cool and creamy, and the sprouts are a fun and fresh twist. I do not usually use spouts in my cooking, but I love them when I eat them out. I saw them in my supermarket and scooped them right up for this recipe. I plan on using them top top sandwiches and wraps for the next week or 2.

Make these for your next meatless Monday or for your vegetarian friend!

Burgers

  • 2 cans black beans - rinsed and drained
  • 1 can cannellini beans - rinsed and drained
  • 1 large jalapeno, seeds removed
  • ½ red bell pepper
  • 2 cloves of garlic
  • 1 egg
  • 1 cup panko bread crumbs
  • handful cilantro
  • 1 1/2 tsp ground cumin
  • ½-1 tsp chili powder (if you like spice)
  • salt and pepper

Fixins'

  • hamburger buns
  • avocado
  • greens
  • red onion
  • chipotle mayo

Mayo

  • ⅓ cup mayo or light mayo
  • 2 tsp chipotles in adobo (I use the juice and not the actual peppers - can adjust to spice level)

First, give the peppers, garlic, and cilantro a rough dice. Toss them into the food processor and pulse until they are diced fine. Drain and rinse the beans and add them to a large bowl. Using your hands, get in there and “smoosh” the beans up. Of course you can use a fork if you’d like, but my grandmother always said - “a cook’s best tools are her hands.” She still cooks that way today. Add the food processor mix to the beans.

Next, add the seasoning and taste. This is your chance to taste before you add the egg. Add in the egg and mix to combine the mixture. Add panko bread crumbs and stir. These should soak up some of the excess liquid and make the mixture more dry.

At this point, I form my beans into burger patties on parchment paper or a silpat baking mat. Put the burgers into the freezer to firm up for about 1/2 hour - 1 hour. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. You can take the burgers straight from the freezer to the oven. Bake the burgers for 20 minutes on 400 degrees then put them on the broil setting for 3-5 minutes to crisp up the tops.

For the mayo, just mix the 2 together and save for the topping.

To serve, add your burger to the bun, top with chipotle mayo, red onion, avocado, and alfalfa sprouts. I served mine alongside my mango slaw, which I will post later this week. Stay tuned...

item.title: Shrimp Pil-Pil
item.description:
This recipe is my take on one of my favorite appetizers, served at a quaint little Greek restaurant that we used to live by. Since we lived across the street, we frequented Dimitris numerous times, and always ended up with this appetizer since we loved it so much. What we know : it’s spicy, it’s garlicky, and it is crispy and delicious. I think I came pretty close to recreating this recipe on the first try. Before writing this, I did a quick google search and learned that this a common tapas recipe from Spain, called Gambas al Ajillo.

Since returning from our trip to the islands of Belize, I have been craving seafood. On the islands, it is so easy because it is always the fresh catch of the day. I ate fish and seafood every night and loved it. I have been inspired to try more fish dishes and experiment with new types of fish and seafood. I hope to have some new and exciting fish dishes coming up in the near future.

  • 1 serrano chile, diced fine (can sub jalapeno)
  • ½ lb of shrimp - peeled and deveined
  • 5 cloves of garlic, minced
  • 1 scallion, chopped
  • ½ teaspoon red pepper flakes
  • cilantro - minced
  • ~ ¼ cup flour
  • 2 teaspoons olive oil
  • squeeze of lemon, optional

To begin, make sure shrimp are cleaned and patted until completely dry. Add salt and pepper to shrimp and then dunk them in the flour, covering all sides with a light coat. Next prepare your veg. Dice the chile, garlic, and scallion. Add oil to the pan and let it sizzle. Add in just the chile and scallion and let it cook for about 3 minutes. Add your dredged shrimp and let it cook and crisp up. It can take about 3-5 minutes per side, depending on the size of your shrimp.

After you flip the shrimp, add the garlic in. Garlic has a tendency to burn, so we want to prevent this by adding it later. Once the shrimp is almost done, toss everything together in the pan. Add in chili flakes and cilantro and let the flavors marry. Make sure you scrape up all the bits of flavor from the bottom of the pan. Serve with a squeeze of lemon, and even grilled bread to sop up the excess!
item.dc:creator: Kristina Bowser

item.title: Chicken Ka-pita-bobs
item.description:
I know what you are thinking - Is it a kabob or a pita? Well I thought it would be fun to turn the chicken kabobs into a Greek/Lebanese style pita with tzatziki! It spices up your chicken routine and you can make it on the grill. I want to say grilling season is here for good, but who knows with this weather! Hopefully it will turn around in May. Once we start grilling outside, we grill straight through until winter hits. It is so nice to be outside grilling, plus it is less dishes!

This recipe is just a basic and easy marinade. As for the veggies, you can use what you like, I just used onions this time. The tzatziki recipe is actually not my own. I know I am Lebanese and I am positive my gram has a spectacular recipe for this, but I have been making Ina Garten’s recipe for years, and it is just too good to change. It is utterly perfect and we love it every time. I will post a link to it so you can check it out. You can top these pitas with tomatoes, onions, pickles, anything you like. They are healthy and delicious way to jump out of that grilled chicken rut!

Kabobs

  • 2 pounds of chicken breasts or tenders, cut into 1 inch cubes
  • ¼ cup olive oil
  • the juice of 1 lemon
  • 4 garlic cloves, minced or grated
  • 2 teaspoons fresh dill
  • salt and pepper
  • 1 large white onion, cut into chunks
  • skewers

Pitas

  • pitas, I used whole wheat
  • fixins : tomatoes, red onions
  • Tzatziki

I find that if I take the extra time out to marinate the chicken, it comes out juicier in the end. Chop the chicken into equal size cubes and place in a large ziplock bag or in a dish to marinate. Add in a good amount of salt and pepper, then the oil, lemon juice, garlic, and dill. Marinate for at least 3 hours but up to an entire day. Once chicken is marinated, grab your skewers and thread the chicken and the white onion (or veggies), alternating. Grill the skewers until the chicken is cooked through to 165 degrees. Let them rest while you prepare the pitas, tzatziki and toppings.

To make the pita, add a skewer of chicken meat and onions, top with tzatziki and veggies! This recipe can really be adapted to the veggies and toppings you want, so have fun with it.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Bowser

item.title: Light & Bright Lemon Vinaigrette
item.description:
Hey Everyone! I am back from my vacation hiatus and ready to post some light and healthy recipes. I think as soon as spring hits, we all have this mind-set to eat better, grill more, and lighten our food choices. Ironically, today is the first really nice day that feels like spring. The weather has been a real bummer lately, so what better way to “think spring” than a yummy and healthy salad.

This vibrant dressing is a great all around dressing to use for salads. The lemon is bright, the garlic adds a nice bite, and the honey sweetens the whole thing up. It is a really nice, flavorful balance. I used mine on spinach greens with tomatoes and scallions, but you can use yours on any combo.

  • ¼ cup lemon juice
  • ½ cup olive oil (I used a little less than this)
  • 1 clove of garlic, grated
  • 1 teaspoon of honey, can use more if you want it sweeter
  • a pinch of salt and pepper, to taste

This is such a simple vinaigrette to whip up and it is great on any salad. Just whisk all the ingredients in a small bowl and dress greens. As for the actual salad, use whats fresh, use what you’ve got, and mix up what you like!

Do you see that grilled bread up there? I brushed my baguette slices with the dressing and grilled it. It tastes like a tangy garlic bread. It really is the perfect compliment to the salad.

This could also be used as a marinade for chicken, fresh fish, and shrimp!

item.title: Cauliflower Mashers
item.description:
As promised, here is the other side dish to accompany the Easter ham. I know this has been a popular idea for some time now, but I think the roasted garlic in here really brings up the flavor. Lets face it, cauliflower can be boring. However, cauliflower can also be transformed to mimic other things with great results. Here, you can have the creamy and satisfying texture of mashed potatoes, but it is better for you! Don’t get me wrong - this still has a fair amount of butter, but this recipe makes enough for at least 6. So all in all, it is a better way to enjoy your favorite comfort food and get a little added health benefit. Win-Win.

  • 2 heads of cauliflower
  • 6 tablespoons of butter
  • ⅓ cup buttermilk
  • 1 head of roasted garlic (recipe below)

Roasted Garlic

Roasting garlic is a great way to add that delicious garlic flavor, without the serious bite. The roasting process mellows and sweetens the flavor of the garlic. It definitely has its place in cooking, and I think it fits perfectly in mashed potatoes and the like. You start with an entire clove (or 2) of garlic and you slice off the pointed tip, exposing just a tiny bit of each clove. Leave the root end intact. Flip garlic with the root end down and place on a piece of foil. Drizzle with olive oil and a pinch of salt and pepper and cover tightly. Place in the oven on 375 degrees for 50-60 minutes until fragrant and soft. Your house will smell amazing! Once finished, allow to cool. In order to get the cloves out, squeeze close to the root end and the cloves will just pop right out. You can even make this ahead or make multiple and keep in the fridge for other uses.

Cauliflower

Begin by cutting cauliflower off of the stem into smaller pieces. Set a large pot of water on the stove and bring to a boil. Boil the cauliflower until soft, the softer it is, the easier to mash. It took me about 15 minutes to boil. To mash the cauliflower, you can use an immersion blender or a food processor. If you do not have either of these kitchen gadgets, you can boil longer than 15 minutes and use a potato masher, but they will not be as smooth. Add in roasted garlic, butter, and buttermilk and mash together until desired creaminess. Add in a good amount of salt and fresh cracked black pepper. This is another extremely easy side dish and a really great way to “healthify” your meal. So go ahead, go for seconds!

item.title: Jazzed Up Peas
item.description:
When I claimed a free ham from my grocery store for the holidays, we decided to have an impromptu Easter dinner. Unfortunately, I had to work Easter day. Lucky for me, my husband was in charge of the shopping, the ham, and all the prep! A 12 lb ham can be a bit much for just 2 people (can you say leftovers?), so we decided to invite the family over to join. I have had 2 recipe ideas for great sides to go with the ham bouncing around in my head for a week or so. I have always loved the classic combination of ham with peas and mashed potatoes. I decided to spruce up the peas and swap out the potatoes, and the results were fantastic! Stay tuned for the “mashed potato” swap...

  • 1 bag frozen peas (can use fresh when in season)
  • 5 slices bacon - chopped
  • half of an onion - chopped
  • approximately 3-4 teaspoons of heavy cream
  • handful of parmesan cheese (⅓ cup)

Begin by boiling the peas for about 5-7 minutes, then drain and rinse under cold water to stop the cooking process. Set aside and leave draining to remove most of the water.

Heat a cast iron or heavy bottomed skillet and add bacon once hot. Use a wooden spoon to break apart pieces and cook until crispy. Once crispy, remove bacon from pan and leave all the bacon grease. Throw in onions and saute for 5-7 minutes, until softened. Add in the peas and saute together for a few minutes, but not too long. You want the peas to stay crisp and not mushy. When I made these, I swirled 4 turns around the pan with the cream. Then add cheese and let the flavors meld. Add a little salt and pepper to taste at the end, but keep in mind the bacon and cheese are salty. That is it! This is a simple and really delicious way to jazz up your peas and is really nice along side a nice holiday ham.
